primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The transformation of the human self from an 'old self' (defined by greed and anxiety) to a 'new self' (defined by generosity and gratitude) through the sacramental and creative power of God.

subject.identificatie: God / The Creator / The Lord of the Narrative
tekstueel_bewijs: the new self which is being renewed... according to the image of its creator
What is impossible for mortals is possible for God
Before God finishes with us, we shall be new selves

object.identificatie: The New Self (A self constituted by generosity and gratitude)
tekstueel_bewijs: clothe yourselves with the new self
a rooted self that does not give in to the narrative of consumer capitalism

zender.identificatie: God (as the source of the 'Impossible' possibility)
tekstueel_bewijs: What is impossible for mortals is possible for God
consider how you yourself are clothed
It is in baptism that the self is radically redefined
The Eucharist is the meal of generosity that breaks the vicious cycles

tegenstander.identificatie: The Narrative of Consumer Capitalism / The Old Self
tekstueel_bewijs: the narrative of anxious greed that propels our consumer society
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just a bad habit but a 'narrative' and a 'system' (Empire/Capitalism) that constitutes the very identity of the person, making change 'impossible' for mortals.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The practice of stewardship (giving/generosity) as a result of the new identity.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The New Self (The Hearer)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The sermon argues that the 'old self' cannot be a steward. The primary program (God making a new self) must precede the secondary program (the self acting as a steward).

voorbeelden_god_subject: The Lord of the narrative said
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We try on the new clothing

voorbeelden: just as the Lord has forgiven you, so you must also forgive
hoping for another way beyond our old grim, tired selves
will not ever be able to be generous
What is impossible for mortals is possible for God

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon centers on 'Incompetence' (the inability of the old self to act) and 'Divine Competence' (God's power to do the impossible).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S2 (Old Self) to ~S2 (The realization of impossibility) to S1 (The Gift of God).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved not by human effort but by the 'Impossible' intervention of God through Sacraments.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Very high; S2 is described as a totalizing narrative of Empire and Capitalism.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon uses imperatives ('clothe yourselves'), it grounds the possibility of action entirely in God's prior work and the 'impossibility' of the human subject acting alone.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: What is impossible for mortals is possible for God.
which is being renewed in knowledge

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures are used primarily as 'case studies' of the Old Self's failure, rather than heroes to emulate.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already treats them as examples of the need for God's intervention.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the 'rat-race' and the burden of self-creation.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic sanctification (God is the one who finishes the work).

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon maintains a tight link between identity (being) and stewardship (doing).
spanning_punten: The tension between 'clothe yourselves' (active) and 'being renewed' (passive).

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: redefined by the mystery of generosity... perfection of our baptism

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is an 'unwelcome table' and a 'narrative' that traps the subject.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully positions God as the primary Subject of transformation, making stewardship a fruit of a new identity rather than a work of the old law.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The hearer might still feel the weight of 'trying on' the clothes.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that the 'clothing' is a gift handed to the subject, not a costume they must sew.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The focus on 'Impossibility' is the sermon's greatest strength.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterful example of grace-oriented preaching that addresses the 'how' of the Christian life by looking at the 'who' of God's action.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'four case studies' structure; Greimas reveals that all four share the same actantial failure (the Old Self as an incompetent Subject).
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains Colossians 3; Greimas shows how the sermon uses Colossians 3 to re-map the hearer's ontological status.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'crisis of stewardship' is actually a crisis of the 'Subject'—the old subject is actantially incapable of the Object (Generosity).

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'Impossible/Possible' dialectic to shift the actantial burden from the Hearer to God.
